posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

posts.com:
English will be the main (ie, most widely spoken) language for a very long time. Secularism is central to Irish Republicanism and always has been, and it's highly unlikely that it would ever go away.
>but why can't they just relearn Irish?
The status of the Irish language in Ireland is thus:
>Republic of Ireland
Everyone learns it in school, a bit. It's treated generally as an afterthought; the vast majority of people know a handful of words, many know a few phrases, some can hold a semi-coherent conversation. A lot are in that stage of learning a language where they recognise/can understand things, but can't really speak it themselves. There exists many gaeltachts where everyone is fluent, but they remain firmly a small minority.
>Northern Ireland
Ulster Unionists get scared by it so it's still widely suppressed. Where it is spoken (Derry, Belfast, etc) it's spoken well and widely.

It's highly likely that Irish will remain the "first" language and the "official" language. We are seeing a new age of revival kickstarting (Irish language speakers in the north are the instigators of it) which is snowballing quite quickly; countless resources are being secured and used to develop grassroots Irish language courses. Don't get too excited-we're decades away from noticeable change.

All this aside, the notion that partition can continue mostly relies on Ulster Unionism keeping hold of a majority in the north-they no longer have that. In fact, Sinn Féin are now the largest party. Unionism bleeds votes to the "centre" which bleeds votes to Nationalism. Ireland will be united but it won't be the happening everyone hopes for-that'll come after unification happens.

Here's the boring answer to muh "United Ireland" debate that nobody wants to accept because it doesn't fulfil their own fantasy of a big happening or a big denial of a happening.

Popularity of opinions on the matter haven't shifted much since the end of the Troubles, in a sense. Generally, according the majority of polls, pro-Union attitudes still slightly outnumber pro-Unity attitudes. There's no plan for a border poll, no big national document on it, no real official campaign. A few private organisations (such as Ireland's Future/Shared Ireland) work for it but there's fuck all in terms of tangible plans made available to people outside of those examples. >>14378077
It's because Ireland was a colony. At no stage were the Irish considered part of a "Union", they were colonial subjects. The only people in Ireland considered to part of the "British Nation" rather than simply subjects to be exploited were the landed Anglo-Irish aristocracy, and eventually to a lesser extent the Protestant lower classes. In the end religion had little to do with it, as few if any sincere efforts were made to convert Ireland; instead religion was used as an excuse to confiscate land and consolidate English/British control of all land, resources and people in Ireland.

Reminder that as early as the 1860s/1870s the dominant political movement in Ireland was that of Home Rule, which called for:
>Limited self-government in Ireland
>Strong economic and political links with England
>Opposition to radical politics (trade unions, republicanism, independence, etc)
Those who spearheaded the call for Home Rule were of the Protestant Anglo-Irish landed class. The most radical political upheaval in Ireland was lead by them via the land reform movement-a movement intended to improve the lot of Irish civilians within the context of British rule.

As late as 1910, the question in Ireland was not "independence from Britain, or rule from Britain" but rather exactly what form of British rule should be adopted. Despite this, the sheer might of British malice (and incompetence) toward Ireland allowed for separatist, republican and revolutionary politics to re-emerge and eventually cause most of the island to secede.

>>14378240
Basically there were 2 major stages of English expansion into Ireland.
>Pre-Protestant
This was in the wake of the Norman Invasion, when Ireland was split between independent Gaelic Kingdoms and Norman lords of dubious loyalty to England. England governed their lands indirectly by entrusting them to powerful Irish-Norman lords.
>Post Reformation
The aforementioned descendants of Normans were mostly Catholic and were increasingly "Gaelic"-they were moreso part of Ireland and Irish society than England. Starting in the 1500s, powerful Irish-Norman lords came increasingly into conflict with English kings, and when you throw Protestantism into the mix the divide was harsher. Starting with Henry VIII swapping out the Lordship of Ireland (Papal Title) for the Kingdom of Ireland and pushing for centralised rule, things shifted away from the feudal approach and toward a colonial approach.

England set up plantations and colonies across Ireland, and tried to bring powerful Irish lords onside by "incorporating" them (surrender and regrant) and eroding their authority in their own lands, before send in English Sheriffs to impose English customs, law, and control. This all came to a head in the late 1500s with the Nine Years War (not to be confused with the continental war of the same name) which ended with the collapse and exile of the remaining Gaelic order in Ireland. England then spent the 1600s consolidating their rule by confiscating land en masse and placing it in the hands of colonists. Throughout the 1600s, Irish Catholics went from owning most to the land to owning less than 20%, despite being a strong majority. Ireland was seen as a colony, not as an integral part of England.

Religion was a means, not an end. The lackluster efforts to convert the Irish were largely abandoned by the mid 1600s. The real issue there was language, and the fact that almost immediately Protestantism became associated with oppressive administrations and land confiscations. Waggling an "Irish language bible" in the rare and sporadic situations where they were used doesn't mean England exhausted every possible peaceful avenue of integration. If we say England "became Protestant" in the 1530s or so, we can see that Ireland had 3 major rebellions over English policy in Ireland-not religion, with religious animosity only being one factor in growing rivalries between local lords and England.

If we circle around to "religion was the only reason Ireland was treated different to wales", then why wasn't Ireland converted? The answer is that England's failures in Ireland preceded the religious differences, and any efforts to convert Ireland were shouted down by attempts to subdue it, regardless of the costs on the "integration" front.

>>14378423
>16th Century wars concerned with Catholics being equal
The main conflicts of the 16th century were to do with conflict between the FitzGeralds and English centralisation; religious animosity played a factor as I mentioned, but it was more as catalyst for escalating an already existing conflict. The 17th Century of course was different; the catalyst for the Confederate Era was an attempt by Irish Catholic plotters to secure the Graces, but even they evolved into a more complex conflict that had more to do with government; the Catholic Confederacy fell into a state of de-facto civil war over an alliance with English Royalists, for example.
>The Irish saw themselves as in a union with Britain
The vast majority didn't at the time; Irish Jacobites were devoted to the Kingdom of Ireland, not incorporation into Britain. A key part of said Kingdom of Ireland (the version of Irish "statehood" at the time) was a Catholic monarchism and the loyalty to the Stuarts. The reason they didn't try to elect an Irish King in the 1600s is because the Gaelic aristocracy by the mid 1600s had either been eliminated or brought forcefully in line with England's governance. So even those who were *most* loyal to the notion of Catholic "English" rule did so out of the fact that the Kingdom of Ireland was demonstrably *not* England, and that their faith, culture and property would no longer be persecuted; Protestantism, conversely, equated to the loss of all 3.

Which Church do I join if I believe that:

1. Asceticism and the doing of good works are essential. (Personally I am fond of the Desert Fathers)

5. The status of the deuterocanonical books is questionable.
6. The papacy is not a divinely instituted office.
7. Veneration of images is not an apostolic tradition, but the creation of images for decorative or educational purposes is acceptable.
8. Prayer to Mary and the saints is acceptable but can go overboard into idolatry. Christ should always be the one to whom we primarily direct our prayers.
9. The only true ecumenical councils, constituting the entire Church, were Nicaea I and Constantinople I. Anyone who holds to the Nicene Creed is a Christian.

For whatever it's worth, I was baptized in a Baptist Church as a young man, but fell away and have not been to Church in some years. There is also a limited selection of churches in my area. >the modern notion of the Papacy from Vatican I is not supported at all.

The formula of Pope Hormisdas settled the first schism between East and West in AD 519:

>The first condition of salvation is to keep the norm of the true faith and in no way to deviate from the established doctrine of the Fathers. For it is impossible that the words of our Lord Jesus Christ, who said, "Thou art Peter, and upon this rock I will build my Church," should not be verified. And their truth has been proved by the course of history, for in the Apostolic See the Catholic religion has always been kept unsullied....
>And so I hope I may deserve to be associated with you in the one communion which the Apostolic See proclaims, in which the whole, true, and perfect security of the Christian religion resides. I promise that from now on those who are separated from the communion of the Catholic Church, that is, who are not in agreement with the Apostolic See, will not have their names read during the sacred mysteries. But if I attempt even the least deviation from my profession, I admit that, according to my own declaration, I am an accomplice to those whom I have condemned. I have signed this, my profession, with my own hand, and I have directed it to you, Hormisdas, the holy and venerable pope of Rome.

The Formula of Hormisdas, which the Eastern bishops signed, sets out the sum and substance of the papal claim as stated in Vatican I.

Fr. Alexander Schmemann agrees:
>Even more characteristic of this eternal compromise with Rome was the signing of the formula of Pope Hormisdas by the Eastern bishops in 519, ending the thirty-year schism between Rome and Constantinople.
>The whole essence of the papal claims cannot be more clearly expressed than in this document, which was imposed upon the Eastern bishops. (Historical Road of Eastern Orthodoxy, 241)

>>14376255
The literal definition of atheism:
>"a-" = without
>"-theism" = the belief in a god or gods
>atheism = without the belief in a god or gods; more succintly, "without the belief in a god or gods"
Strictly speaking, an atheist is, or rather ought, to be someone who simply lacks the belief in any sort of divine power.
However, that literal definition is rarely adhered to in the real world.
Most people who call themselves "atheists" or subscribe to "atheism" are not merely "without" belief, in fact quite the opposite, they BELIEVE, wholeheartedly, and with the knowledge certitude of faith, that there is no god or gods. These "atheists" are in fact "anti-theists" - people who are against theism altogether, instead of merely lacking theism. These are the people who are often described as "militant" atheists, and tend to be reviled everywhere and by everybody, including real, genuine atheists, who typically mask their atheism with the word "agnostic", in order to avoid being associated with people who have made a religion out of being against religion.
"Gnosis" is the Greek word for "knowledge" so an agnostic is a person "without knowledge", i.e. has not been convinced of any evidence in point of favor for theism or against it, and thus takes the actual atheistical view in its literal definition, that to have no knowledge is to have no belief.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14378773
>Just like why we're speaking today English : American Hegemony is the true reason, but since it doesn't please the British Ego, British pretend it's due to the mighty British Empire ...
Firstly, even if that were true the reason America exists is because of the British Empire. Seems like a distinction you'd only make if you were butthurt about the British.

Secondly, it isn't true. It's ironic that you say the British are parochial, because the idea that English only became common because of America is a statement you only make if you have the attitude that nothing outside Europe really counts. There are a lot of countries in Asia and Africa where English is a co-official language and the elites, and quite often a large segment of the population, speak English because they're former British colonies. Sometimes they're not even former colonies, just places where the British were influential; a lot of the upper class Chinese who speak English learned it at Oxford rather than Harvard.

But even if you're only talking about Europe, it's still not true. English had largely displaced French as the main language of international communication for practical purposes by the end of the 19th century. French was still used officially in diplomatic circles (always a conservative profession), and it was still common, but if you were a businessman with international connections, or an engineer who wanted to study abroad, or just someone who enjoyed travel, then you would likely know some English. A good illustration of this is how the Russian court spoke French almost exclusively at the beginning of the 19th century, but Tsar Nicholas II spoke English so fluently he could be mistaken for British, and barely used French.

Of course, Europe only became essentially universally bilingual in English among younger generations after WW2, but before the rise of mass media most people only knew the language, or languages, that were spoken in their country anyway.

posts.com: What does it imply when someone claims something is impossible? He is only expressing his perspective about how the world functions, in my opinion. The fact that something happened under certain conditions does not indicate that it was inevitable since something else may have happened by chance instead of causing the ostensibly inevitable result. People often argue that Hitler couldn't have won World War II, but what if Hitler had just been luckier? What if the outcome of the Battle of Stalingrad was different? Imagine if the Allies had chosen a different course of action. What if the United States had avoided starting a war altogether? What if, under Stalin, the Soviet Union had not rearmed? And so on. Hitler may have triumphed regardless of how he behaved. Saying it was "impossible" ignores all the other alternative outcomes. Nothing is impossibly possible since conditions are always liable to change. Trump won't necessarily lose the next election just because he didn't win this one.

A DNA test can be used to obtain Israeli citizenship, but this is reserved to prove that a person is the child of an Israeli citizen. According to Israeli law, if a child is born to an Israeli mother or father abroad, they can be granted Israeli citizenship. The DNA test is used to authorize this, proving this familial link. We discuss more about obtaining a paternity test in Israel in another article.

No, for many reasons like >>14374542 said, but I'll also mention that Homo erectus and Homo habilis were long extinct by 124,000 years ago (the oldest known admixture event between Homo sapiens and this unknown species), and that Eastern, Southern, and Central African hunter-gatherers have two unknown species of human in them, yet they don't appear to get the same racism against them as West Africans do. >>14378228
Communism, being a completely stateless and classless society, is probably only realistically achievable after generations after a transition from capitalism and probably involving some kind of Star Trek like zero-scarcity future.

Socialism is the transition phase, classes and the state still exist, but the state acts on behalf of the working classes rather than the capitalist class. Marxism is a school of thought that derives heavily from the works of Karl Marx, which is focused on studying history, class struggle, political economy, capitalism and also on how to transition away from it.

Marx himself broadly used socialism and communism interchangeably to denote a classless society where property is owned, exploited, and enjoyed collectively by the people. Lenin made a further distinction that socialism is the transitional state between capitalism and communism, where a new state apparatus must be built and maintained in order to secure, protect, and grow the gains of a workers' revolution that significantly reduces the power of the existing ruling class. This is a major point of contention between socialists/communists and anarchists (who believe that we can have a classless society immediately following that revolution without an intermediary state).

Anyways predictions provided by historical materialism undergirds Marx's assertions that capitalism is suicidal as a mode of production and that the material conditions created by capitalism are what will force an inevitable march toward democratic collectivization (socialism), and since the same methodology predicted pretty much everything about modern capitalism, I'd say there's good odds.

Also the whole Norman and Plantagenet debate is getting tiresome. Yes England was irrevocably transformed since 1066. The language is nothing like Old English, the given names are mostly continental or Biblical based, and those of Norman descent are usually in positions of power and influence. But the exchange went both ways. The invaders' descendants adapted to the English tongue, thus Middle English was formed. The populace remained stubbornly English in sentiments and absorbed the French-speaking nobility into a new kind of Englishness. The limits to absolutist kingship and representation in assemblies was reasserted through the Barons' Wars and as the merchant class grew in wealth and influence so did the advent of the gentry, which arose from the Anglo-Saxon minor nobility and administrators that ran things from the Norman and Plantagenet dynasties.

England's greatness in the 1600s to early 1900s was a reaction to the near 400 years of French domination. In spite of wasteful wars over French territory and brutal subjugation of the English masses, the political and social development had England move to mercantile affairs, interest in the arts and sciences, and for the idea of constitutional monarchy. These seeds are what helped birth the United States, Canada and New Zealand; the most successful settler colonies and all rich developed nations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14378619
The Roman Empire wasn’t a monarchy, it was a Republic so there was no such thing as “succession”. The Imperial Office was the accumulation of multiple earlier Republican offices into one, and to be considered legitimate you needed the support of three sources (officially). The Senate, the People of Rome (later Constantinople), and the Army. Technically the Army was the most important one to have since it could threaten the other two, but even then most emperors sought senatorial approval, even in the Late Empire, and they also tried to rally the people of the capital behind them. The only way for a person to bypass this was for an emperor to raise them up to the position of co-emperor. This was done quite often in the Late empire, and Byzantine period as a means of effectively governing a large empire, and ensuring stability once an emperor died, and usually a son, or relative was chosen, but not always. If things were going poorly this opened the way for rivals to try and oust the emperor. Their legitimacy hinges on the very republican notion of popular support, not divine inheritance. Blood relation to previous emperors could only get you so far.

>>14380422
>What is the difference between Baptists and Anabaptists?
These are just names for different congregations. You will find different people using different definitions sometimes, so you'll have to probe a little deeper about what a particular people believe to know whether they are doctrinally sound or not. That can only happen if you first believe the Holy Bible yourself.

But as a general answer to this question, baptists are related to the group of Christian churches that came down from antiquity with the New Testament ecclesiology intact, and the name specifically points to the fact that they still do baptism as it is done in the New Testament of the Bible. The name in particular is a shortened form of the term "anabaptist" which was given to the baptists as a form of derision around the 16th century, although a similar name was used against them in Justinian's laws and before that in Honorius' laws where they were called "rebaptizandi". This name carries the same signification as the later term "anabaptist." See Imperatoris Theodosii codex: Book 16, Title 6 and Codex Justinianus Book 1, Title 6 for that reference.

Meanwhile, the anabaptists today generally refers to groups descended and related to the "Swiss Brethren" who followed the Schleitheim Confession of 1527. The difference is that these groups tend to follow many more rules and regulations than are found in the Bible, such as the Amish and Mennonites, and they are the only ones that actually identified themselves under the moniker "anabaptist."

>What is the Southern and Independent Baptist view of the New Independent Fundamentalist Baptists (NIFB) lead by Steven Anderson?

Now most people dismiss it entirely, saying that the United States gets most of its oil domestically and from Canada anyway and doesn't give a shit about Iraqi oil.

But I think that's projecting present experience onto the past. People were shit scared of peak oil during the 00s, the peak oil movement had over 100,000 "peakists" at its peak (heh). The 1970s oil shocks weren't too long ago and the United States still had an apprensive paranoia at spiking oil prices, and they were going up since the glut in the 80s, and showed no signs of slowing down.

I don't believe that the United States literally invaded to seize Iraqi oil to export it to the United States. But I do believe they came down hard to prevent OPEC from having another oil producing member that could throw its weight around in the middle east, and to prevent Ba'thist Iraq from being a wildcard in the Middle Eastern balance of power.

De-Baathification in Iraq came with the privatizing of the oil fields. Full privatization was underway and it was only a changing of circumstances, with dropping oil demand due to the financial recession and the fracking boom in the States, that made the US government relent on the most extreme elements of privatization.

I do believe that there was a strong possibility that if oil scarcity became a serious problem and Iraq got back on its feet, there was a possibility of a Saudi/Iraq rapprochement. The worst autistic tantrums the Arabs had over Israel were over at that point, and there wasn't much chance of the States getting back in with Iran. The US would've ended up locked out of the middle east and be unable to dictate the flow of oil leaving the region.

Russia was also exerting its own independence under Putin and gone were the days of the 90s when the States could literally dictate terms. The OPEC crisis was only mitigated in Europe in the 70s by the Brezhnev administrations eagerness to get its hand on foreign cash. A rising Russia without the retarded communist economic system might be in a position to not bail Europe out next time, and going by how much Europe suffered without Russian oil this time, this theory has been pretty well vindicated. A repeat of the 70s without Russian gas would've horrifically tanked the European economy, to the point where it'd take over a decade to recover.

All this seems somewhat silly now only because we've had a fracking boom and a rise in unconventional oil. The oil hypothesis for the Iraq war makes the most sense, and can explain every part of the war sufficiently. The idealistic war on terror explanation can't.

John 1 doesn't teach Jesus' equality with God. This scripture reveals details about Jesus Christ’s life before he came to earth as a human. (John 1:14-17) In verse 14, “the Word” (or “the Logos,” Greek, ho loʹgos) is used as a title. The title “the Word” describes Jesus’ role in communicating God’s commands and instructions to others. Jesus continued to make known God’s word during his ministry on earth and after he returned to heaven.—John 7:16; Revelation 1:1.

“The beginning” refers to the time when God began his creative work and produced the Word. Thereafter, the Word was used by God in the creation of all other things. (John 1:2, 3) The Bible states that Jesus is “the firstborn of all creation” and that “by means of him all other things were created.”—Colossians 1:15, 16.

The phrase “the Word was a god” describes the divine or godlike nature that Jesus possessed before he came to earth. He can be described in this way because of his role as God’s Spokesman and his unique position as the firstborn Son of God through whom God created all other things.

posts.name: JWanon

>>14374984
it is important to address a large problem that exists where you do not have the proper understanding of what the literal definition of "angel" in the Bible is.

Both the Hebrew mal·´akh´ and the Greek ag´ge·los literally mean “messenger.” When spirit messengers are indicated, the words are translated “angels,” but if the reference definitely is to humans, the rendering is “messengers.” (Gen. 16:7; 32:3; Jas. 2:25; Rev. 22:8)

Whether human or angelic messengers are meant can be determined by the context.

When Jesus was on earth, he was God's foremost messenger. He was called the "Word" because he was God's Spokesman. (John 12:49, 50; 14:10; 7:16, 17)

Jesus is not just an angel. Scripture suggests that he is the Archangel. Archangel means “chief angel.” And since the term “archangel” occurs in the Bible only in the singular, never in the plural, this suggests that there is only one such angel.

Moreover, Jesus is linked with the office of archangel. Regarding the resurrected Lord Jesus Christ, 1 Thessalonians 4:16 states: “The Lord himself will descend from heaven with a commanding call, with an archangel’s voice.” Thus the voice of Jesus is described as being that of an archangel. This Scripture therefore suggests that Jesus himself is the archangel Michael !

This is what the Shepherd says:

>3[31]:1 "I will still proceed, Sir," say I, "to ask a further question." "Speak on," saith he. "I have heard, Sir," say I, "from certain teachers, that there is no other repentance, save that which took place when we rent down into the water and obtained remission of our former sins."
>3[31]:2 He saith to me; "Thou hast well heard; for so it is. For he that hath received remission of sins ought no longer to sin, but to dwell in purity.
>3[31]:3 But, since thou enquirest all things accurately, I will declare unto thee this also, so as to give no excuse to those who shall hereafter believe or those who have already believed, on the Lord. For they that have already believed, or shall hereafter believe, have not repentance for sins, but have only remission of their former sins.
>3[31]:4 To those then that were called before these days the Lord has appointed repentance. For the Lord, being a discerner of hearts and foreknowing all things, perceived the weakness of men and the manifold wiles of the devil, how that he will be doing some mischief to the servants of God, and will deal wickedly with them.
>3[31]:5 The Lord then, being very compassionate, had pity on His handiwork, and appointed this (opportunity of) repentance, and to me was given the authority over this repentance.
>3[31]:6 But I say unto you," saith he, "if after this great and holy calling any one, being tempted of the devil, shall commit sin, he hath only one (opportunity of) repentance. But if he sin off-hand and repent, repentance is unprofitable for such a man; for he shall live with difficulty."
>3[31]:7 I say unto him, "I was quickened unto life again, when I heard these things from thee so precisely. For I know that, if I shall add no more to my sins, I shall be saved." "Thou shalt be saved," he saith, "thou and all, as many as shall do these things."

I'm guessing this is building off of what Hebrews 10:26-27 says.
